Yes, I did sign a petition in Le Monde. Entitled Nous defendons une liberte... (<<We defend a freedom...>>), that petition has sparked a range of reactions. I felt it should be clarified. Yes, I love freedom. I do not like that we live in a time when everyone feels they have the right to set themselves up as judge, jury and executioner. A time when mere accusations on social media lead to punishment, resignation and sometimes - indeed often - trial by media. A time when an actor can be digitally removed from a film, and the head of a respected New York institution made to immediately resign for grabbing butts thirty years ago. I'm not making excuses for these men. I pass no judgment on their guilt or innocence; I am not qualified to do so. Very few people are. And, no, I do not like the mob mentality that is far too common today. This is why, as early as October, I had reservations about the Balance ton porc (<<Expose Your Pig>>) hashtag. I'm not naive. I know that far more men exhibit these kinds of behaviors than women. But isn't this hashtag an open invitation to naming and shaming? How can we be sure that there is no manipulation or vindictiveness? That the wrongly accused will not end up taking their lives? I believe we should live together, and stay away from <<pig>> or <<slut>> name-calling. I must admit to finding the text of the petition compelling, if not entirely perfect. Yes, I signed the petition. Yet I feel strongly compelled to voice my disagreement today with the way some signatories have appointed themselves media spokespersons, twisting the essential meaning of the text in the process. To state on national television that a woman can climax during rape is worse than spitting in the faces off all women who have had to endure such a crime. These words suggest to those who use force, or manipulate sexuality for destructive purposes, that it's OK to do so, simply because the victim may have an orgasm. When one has signed one's name next to those of others, it is important to show some restraint, and not implicate them in your own verbal incontinence. Not doing so is disgraceful. Of course, nowhere in the petition does it say that there is anything good about harassment, or I would not have signed it. I have been an actress since the age of 17. Clearly, I could say that I have witnessed things that were more than improper, or that I know via other actresses that some film-makers have abused their power in cowardly ways. But it is not for me to speak up for my colleagues. Traumatizing, intolerable situations are always the result of power, hierarchy or some form of control. We are trapped once it becomes impossible to say no without risking our jobs or undergoing humiliation and degrading remarks. I think the solution lies in educating both our sons and daughters. But also, potentially, in setting up procedures in the workplace so that prosecution is immediately set in motion in cases of harassment. I believe in justice. Lastly, I signed this petition for a reason that is, to me, fundamental: the danger of purges in the arts. Are we going to burn leather-bound copies of Sade? Decide that Leonardo da Vinci is a pedophile artist and obliterate his paintings? Pull down Gauguin from gallery walls? Destroy the sketches of Egon Schiele? Ban the music of Phil Spector? This climate of censorship shocks me and makes me fearful for the future of our societies. I am sometimes criticized for not being a feminist. Must I point out that I was one of the 343 self-described <<sluts>>, along with Marguerite Duras and Francoise Sagan, who signed the Je me suis fait avorter (<<I have had an abortion>>) manifesto, penned by Simone de Beauvoir? At the time, under French law, having an abortion could lead to prosecution and imprisonment. This is why I want to say to conservatives, racists and reactionaries of all stripes who have found it convenient to support me that I am not fooled. They will not win my gratitude, nor my friendship; quite the opposite in fact. I am a free woman, and will remain so. Let me acknowledge those of my fellow women who have been the victims of abhorrent acts and felt offended by the article in Le Monde. I apologize to them, and to them alone. Yours sincerely, Catherine Deneuve Translated from the French by Alice Heathwood and Bamiyan Shiff for Fast for Word. partager tweeter Le journal du jour en exclusivite et le journal de demain avant tout le monde De la <<liberte d'importuner>> au droit de ne pas l'etre partager tweeter Here is the English version of Catherine Deneuve's letter published in Liberation on Monday in response to the open letter she signed in Le Monde along 100 prominent women that argued the campaign against sexual harassement had gone too far.
